questions.text: A child is brought by her parents to the OPD with complaints of crossed eyes as shown below. By doing a simple torchlight test you conclude that the child has pseudostrabismus and the inter-pupillary distance is normal. Which of the following can be associated with the child's condition?
questions.solution:
The child has pseudoesotropia (apparent convergent squint) which is associated with negative angle kappa and epicanthal folds.

Pseudostrabismus—apparent squint (visual axes are parallel, but eyes seem to have a squint)

Types:

  • Pseudoesotropia
    • Apparent convergent squint
    • Prominent epicanthal fold
    • Negative angle kappa
  • Pseudoexotropia
    • Apparent divergent squint
    • Hypertelorism
    • Positive angle kappa - due to retinopathy of prematurity, hypermetropia

 

Few definitions: 

  • Orthophoria- implies perfect ocular alignment in the absence of any stimulus for fusion
  • Heterophoria ("phoria")- implies a tendency of the eyes to deviate when fusion is blocked (latent squint)
  • Heterotropia ("tropia")- implies a manifest deviation in which the visual axes do not intersect at the point of fixation
  • Hypertropia- upward displacement of one eye relative to the other is termed as hypertropia and a latent upward imbalance, a hyperphoria
  • Hypotropia- downward displacement is termed a hypotropia and a latent imbalance, a hypophoria

Related Pearl: Classification of Strabismus

  • Pseudostrabismus—Apparent squint
    • Pseudo esotropia
    • Pseduo exotropia
  • Heterophoria—Latent squint
    • Esophoria: Convergent
    • Exophoria: Divergent
    • Hyperphoria: Deviation upwards
    • Hypophoria: Deviation downwards
    • Cyclophoria: Rotation around AP axis
  • Heterotropia—Manifest squint
  • Concomitant
    • Amount of deviation remains constant in all directions of gaze.
    • Esotropia: Convergent
      • Infantile
      • Accommodative
      • Sensory
      • Consecutive
    • Exotropia: Divergent
      • Congenital
      • Primary
      • Secondary: Sensory deprived
      • Consecutive
    • Hypertropia: Vertical squint
  • Incomitant
    • Amount of deviation varies in different directions of gaze
      • Paralytic squint
      • Restrictive squint
      • A and V pattern heterotropia

questions.text: A child presents to the OPD with a mild squint. The rest of the history is quite insignificant. On examination, Hirschberg's corneal reflex test is found to be normal. All other eye parameters are also normal except for hypertelorism. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of pseudoexotropia.

Features of Pseudoexotropia:

  • Normal Hirschberg's corneal reflex test
  • Apparent divergent squint
  • Associated with hypertelorism/a positive angle kappa.

Related Pearl: Classification of Strabismus

  • Pseudostrabismus—Apparent squint
    • Pseudo esotropia
    • Pseduo exotropia
  • Heterophoria—Latent squint
    • Esophoria: Convergent
    • Exophoria: Divergent
    • Hyperphoria: Deviation upwards
    • Hypophoria: Deviation downwards
    • Cyclophoria: Rotation around AP axis
  • Heterotropia—Manifest squint
  • Concomitant
    • Amount of deviation remains constant in all directions of gaze.
    • Esotropia: Convergent
      • Infantile
      • Accommodative
      • Sensory
      • Consecutive
    • Exotropia: Divergent
      • Congenital
      • Primary
      • Secondary: Sensory deprived
      • Consecutive
    • Hypertropia: Vertical squint
  • Incomitant
    • Amount of deviation varies in different directions of gaze
      • Paralytic squint
      • Restrictive squint
      • A and V pattern heterotropia

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is least likely to present with diplopia?
questions.solution:
Latent squint does not always present with diplopia.

Heterophoria (Latent squint) is a condition in which the tendency of the eyes to deviate is kept latent by fusion. When the influence of fusion is removed, the visual axis of one eye deviates away.

Types:

  • Esophoria-convergent
  • Exophoria-divergent
  • Hyperphoria-deviation upwards
  • Hypophoria-deviation downwards
  • Cyclophoria-rotation around AP axis

Symptoms:

  • Usually asymptomatic-compensated type.
  • In cases where there are symptoms-decompensated type
    • Headache
    • Eye ache
    • Photophobia
    • Intermittent diplopia (only under fatigue – temporarily)

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common type of squint seen in children?
questions.solution:
Accommodative esotropia is the most common type of squint seen in children.

Most common type of squint overall: accommodative esotropia

Second most common overall: congenital/Infantile esotropia

Most common type of exotropia: primary exotropia

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding comitant squint?

choices.text: No co-relation between primary and secondary deviations

questions.solution:
In comitant squint (concomitant), the primary deviation is equal to the secondary deviation.

Primary deviation = Deviation of the squinting eye

Secondary deviation = Deviation of the normal eye under cover when the patient fixes with the squinting eye.

In incomitant (paralytic and restrictive squint), secondary deviation > primary deviation due to Herring's Law of equal innervation.

questions.text: A mother noticed that her child has had malaligned eyes since birth but she couldn't afford treatment due to financial constraints.  She now presents at 2-months of age and the child has the following finding on examination. An ophthalmoscopic examination under full cycloplegia reveals no abnormalities in refraction and media. Cranial nerves are intact. Which of the following statements is true regarding this condition?

choices.text: Angle of deviation is large and constant.
Amblyopia develops in 90 % of the cases.
It is associated with latent vertical nystagmus.
Correction by spectacles is the treatment of choice.

questions.solution:
The age at presentation, esotropia, no refractory error, no media opacities, and no cranial nerve palsies suggest a diagnosis of essential infantile esotropia. The angle of deviation in infantile esotropia is fairly large (> 30°) and constant.

Infantile esotropia, also known as non-accommodative esotropia is the most common type of congenital esotropia.

Clinical features:

  • Comitant convergent squint
  • Age of onset- 1 to 2 months
  • Angle of deviation- large and constant
  • Amblyopia- develops in 25–40% of cases
  • Associations include:
    • Inferior oblique overaction
    • Dissociated vertical deviation (70%)
    • Latent horizontal nystagmus

Treatment:

  • Surgery- treatment of choice
  • Amblyopia correction measures: Patching of normal eye
  • Recession of both medial recti
  • Timing: Preferably before 1 year

questions.text: A surgeon decides to resect a part of a muscle while operating on a case of strabismus. This action would lead to which of the following?

choices.text: No change in strength of the muscle

questions.solution:
In squint surgery, muscle resection leads to the strengthening of the muscle.

The main types of procedure in squint surgery are as follows:

  1. Weakening to decrease the effective strength of action of a muscle.
    • Recession slackens a muscle by moving it away from its insertion. It can be performed on any muscle except the superior oblique.
    • Disinsertion (or myectomy) involves detaching a muscle from its insertion without reattachment. It is most commonly used to weaken an overacting inferior oblique muscle.
    • Posterior fixation suture: The principle of this (Faden) procedure is to suture the muscle belly to the sclera posteriorly so as to decrease the pull of the muscle in its field of action without affecting the eye in the primary position.
  2. Strengthening, to enhance the pull of a muscle.
    • Resection shortens a muscle to enhance its effective pull. It is suitable only for the rectus muscle.
    • Tucking of a muscle or its tendon is usually confined to the enhancement of the action of the superior oblique muscle.
    • Advancement of the muscle nearer to the limbus can be used to enhance the action of a previously recessed rectus muscle.
  3. Vector adjustment procedures have the primary aim of altering the direction of muscle action.
  4. Transposition refers to the relocation of one or more extraocular muscles to substitute for the action of an absent or severely deficient muscle. The most common indication is severe lateral rectus weakness due to acquired palsy of the 6th cranial nerve palsy.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding accommodative esotropia?

choices.text: It is the most common type of squint.
Miotics are used as the treatment strategy in the high AC/A ratio
It is associated with high myopia.
Refractive type can be fully corrected by use of spectacles.

questions.solution:
Accommodative esotropia is associated with a high degree of hypermetropia (+4 to +7 D).

Accommodative esotropia is the most common type of squint. Typically presents around 2 to 3 years of age.

Types:

  1. Refractive
    • Associated with high hypermetropia
    • Fully correctable by spectacles
  2. Non-refractive type
    • Abnormal accommodative convergence/accommodation (AC/A) ratio
    • Fully corrected by bifocal glasses
    • Miotics useful in cases where glasses are unsuitable
      • Echothiophate causes iris cyst
      • Prevention of iris cysts- Phenylephrine drops
  3. Mixed type

The accommodative convergence/accommodation (AC/A) ratio is defined as the amount of convergence measured in prism diopters per unit (diopter) change in accommodation.

The image below shows accommodative esotropia with and without correction.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best line of treatment in a 3-year-old child presenting with a recent onset of 15-degree accommodative esotropia?
questions.solution:
The best line of treatment in accommodative esotropia is a refractive correction.

Esotropia for distance is corrected by the treatment of hypermetropia: convex glasses

Esotropia for near is corrected by +3DS lens.

Algorithm for the management of accommodative esotropia is as follows:

  • R: Refractive correction: Glasses/Miotics
  • O: Orthoptics/Occlusion: for amblyopia
  • O: Operative correction: for non-accommodative component
  • P: Prism correction: for remaining error

questions.text: Charlie, a 5-year-old boy with crossed eyes received his first eye exam from a primary care ophthalmologist. Examination, including cycloplegic refraction and dilated fundus exam, resulted in diagnoses of constant right esotropia, and amblyopia in the right eye. By what age should his amblyopia be corrected?
questions.solution:
Strabismic amblyopia should be corrected before 8 years of age.

The sensitive period during which acuity of an amblyopic eye can be improved is usually up to 7–8 years in strabismic amblyopia and maybe longer (into the teens) for anisometropic amblyopia when a good binocular function is present.

In the absence of an organic lesion, a difference in best-corrected visual acuity (VA) of two Snellen lines or more (or >1 log unit) is indicative of amblyopia.

Treatment of amblyopia:

  1. Occlusion of the normal eye, to encourage the use of the amblyopic eye, is the most effective treatment.
  2. Penalization, in which vision in the normal eye is blurred with atropine, is an alternative method.

questions.text: A 5-year-old female patient presented for her first complete eye examination after a school vision screening found unequal visual acuity. Her parents have not noted any eye problems. Visual acuity in the right eye was 20/20 and the left eye is 20/80. The rest of the examination was unremarkable and glasses were prescribed. She was diagnosed with anisometric hyperopia and amblyopia of the left eye when her visual acuity at a return appointment was found to be 20/20 RE  and 20/60 LE at a distance while wearing her new glasses.  What is the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
Occlusion of the normal eye is the treatment of choice for amblyopia.

Amblyopia is an uncorrectable decrease in vision in one or both eyes with no apparent structural abnormality seen to explain it. It is a diagnosis of exclusion. Generally, a difference of two lines or more on an eye chart test of visual acuity between the two eyes or a best-corrected vision of 20/30 or worse would be defined as amblyopia. For example, our patient has 20/20 vision with the right eye and only 20/80 with the left and the left eye even after best-corrected vision couldn't achieve <20/30 vision, the left eye is said to be amblyopic.

Clinical features:

  • Decreased contrast sensitivity
  • Diminution of vision
  • Sunglass effect- brightness is less compared to the normal eye
  • Crowding phenomenon- slipping of images

Treatment of choice:

  • Occlusion of the normal eye (4 to 6 hours/day) using patches.
  • Penalization: Blurring of vision using atropine.

Prism correction is not the right treatment as the child doesn't have strabismus.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with a right convergent squint of 6 months duration. Choose the most appropriate treatment strategy.

choices.text: Immediate surgical correction followed by amblyopia therapy
Proper refractive correction, amblyopia therapy followed by surgical correction
Prescription of spectacles and defer surgery until 5 years
Botulinum toxin injection followed by occlusion therapy

questions.solution:
The appropriate management in this case would be proper refractive correction, amblyopia therapy followed by surgical correction

The algorithm for management of accommodative squint is as follows:

  • R: Refractive correction: Glasses/Miotics
  • O: Orthoptics/Occlusion: For amblyopia
  • O: Operative correction: For non-accommodative component
  • P: Prism correction: For remaining error

questions.text: In which of the following conditions should an ophthalmologist prescribe miotics?
questions.solution:
Miotics are used in the management of accommodative esotropia.

The use of miotics in convergent strabismus is based on the peripheral spasm of accommodation caused by the drug. The accommodation triad involves convergence. An increased accommodative effort increases the amount of convergence. Pilocarpine would produce accommodation spasm and eliminate the accommodative convergence that would otherwise occur when the patient looks at a near object. It is useful in cases of an abnormal AC/A ratio as in, accommodative esotropia.

questions.text: Paralytic squint presents with all except
questions.solution:
In squint, the deviation of the eye results in two vastly different images. The brain is unable to fuse them. Hence, there is no stereopsis.

Features of paralytic squint:

Symptoms:

  • Diplopia
  • Confusion
  • Nausea, Vertigo
  • Ocular deviation

Signs:

  • Primary deviation < Secondary deviation
  • Compensatory head posture–Ocular torticollis
  • False projection or orientation

In adults- no amblyopia

In children <6 years- amblyopia can occur

questions.text: A 40-year-old diabetic patient presented with the ​squint. On examination, the secondary deviation was found to be more than the primary deviation. Forced duction test is negative. Which of the following types of squint is most likely to be present in this patient?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of paralytic squint. It is characterized by the presence of secondary deviation more than the primary deviation and a negative forced duction test.

The squint may be either comitant or incomitant.

  • Comitant squint: The angle of squint measured is same in all gazes. 
  • Incomitant squint: The angle of squint measured is different in different gazes. 

The differences between comitant and incomitant squint are shown in the table below:

Features Comitant squint Incomitant squint
Magnitude of squint Same in all gazes Varies with the gaze
Diplopia Absent Present
Ocular movements Full Restricted
False projection Absent Present
Abnormal head posture Absent Present
Secondary deviation Equal to primary deviation More than primary deviation

The incomitant squint is further divided into two main types: Paralytic and restrictive.

Paralytic squint occurs due to the paralysis of extraocular muscle while restrictive squint is due to the mechanical restriction caused by tight or fibrosed muscle.

Forced duction test(FDT) differentiates between these two types. In this test, the eye is moved mechanically with the help of a forceps.

  • The test is negative if there is no resistance to the movement. It is seen in a paralytic squint.
  • The test is positive if there is resistance to the movement. It is seen in a restrictive squint.

questions.text: Identify the condition.
questions.solution: The patient has left eye esotropia in primary gaze which is suggestive of left abducent (6th) nerve palsy which innervates the left lateral rectus muscle.

questions.text: A patient complains of difficulty in climbing down the stairs due to double vision. On examination, you notice his right eye has deviated upward and the deviation becomes more pronounced on the left gaze. The remaining extraocular movements are intact. Which nerve is most likely involved?
questions.solution:
The affected nerve in the given clinical scenario is the right trochlear nerve. 

The right trochlear nucleus actually innervates the left superior oblique and vice versa. However, the nerve decussates at the midbrain at the level of the inferior colliculus. So, lesions of the trochlear nucleus lead to contralateral palsy. While that of trochlear nerve peripherally lead to ipsilateral palsy.

In this patient, the right-sided symptoms could be due to a lesion in the right trochlear nerve (ipsilateral) or left trochlear nucleus (contralateral). He complains of diplopia while climbing down the stairs because the normal eye can look down but the paralytic eye has deviated. There is also a limitation of depression due to superior oblique palsy, and hence the eye is deviated upward due to overaction of the inferior oblique. The obliques exert maximum force in an adducted position and hence the deviation becomes more prominent on the left gaze when the right eye is adducted.

questions.text: A patient suffers head trauma following which he complains of diplopia. His extraocular motility testing in the 9 gazes is as shown in the image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario suggests a left oculomotor nerve palsy.

It is evident by the upper lid ptosis and down and out deviation of the left eye, as seen in the primary position of gaze (central image).

questions.text: An 18-year-old destitute woman reports to a free eye camp with vision problems. Best-corrected visual acuity was 6/12 in the right eye and 6/6 in the left eye. Elevation in the right eye was absent. Her right eye showed 14–16 prism diopter (PD) hypotropia. Bell's phenomenon was absent in the right eye. Diagnosis of right eye double elevator palsy was made. Which of the following muscles are affected in her?

choices.text: Levator palpebrae superioris and Muller muscle
Levator palpebrae superioris and superior rectus

questions.solution:
In double-elevator palsy, the muscles involved are superior rectus and inferior oblique.

It is commonly associated with ptosis or pseudoptosis.

questions.text: A patient reports to the OPD with complaints that he feels dizzy on lateral gaze. His range of movements is shown below. Jerky movements are also observed in the left eye on the left gaze however convergence is normal. Which of the following structures is most likely affected?
questions.solution:
Lesion to the medial longitudinal fasciculus causes internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO).

The right gaze is normal but on the left gaze, there is an inability of right eye adduction and in the left abduction is possible but with nystagmus. This along with normal convergence are all in favor of diagnosis of a lesion in right medial longitudinal fasciculus(MLF) leading to internuclear ophthalmoplegia.

INO is seen in multiple sclerosis

The image below depicts internuclear ophthalmoplegia due to a lesion of the right MLF.

 

Total ophthalmoplegia

  • All extraocular and intraocular muscles are paralyzed.
  • Paralysis of 3rd, 4th, and 6th nerve
  • Seen in orbital apex syndrome, cavernous sinus thrombosis

External ophthalmoplegia

  • All extraocular muscles are paralyzed
  • Lesions at the level of motor nuclei
  • Sparing of Edinger Westphal nucleus

questions.text: Identify the condition
questions.solution:
The image shows Duane’s retraction syndrome type 1.

Paradoxical innervation of LR where it gets innervated by some fibres of III nerve instead of VI nerve. On impulse for abduction via VI nerve there is no abduction limitation. On impulse for adduction via III nerve both LR and MR contract thus causing retraction of globe (as the antagonist LR instead of relaxation, starts to contract)

Duane’s retraction syndrome (DRS) is a cause of restrictive squint

There is a failure of innervation of the lateral rectus by a hypoplastic sixth nerve nucleus, with anomalous innervation of the lateral rectus by fibers from the third nerve. Retraction of the globe on attempted adduction. Widening of palpebral fissure on attempted abduction

Classification by Huber:

  • Limitation of abduction- type 1
  • Limitation of adduction- type 2
  • Limitation of both- type 3

Note: DRS is an exception to Sherrington's law of reciprocal innervation.

questions.text: An eleven-year-old girl presented with a history of squint and poor vision. She had visual acuities of 6/24 and counting fingers in her right and left eyes respectively. There was a left hypotropia in the primary position of gaze with associated marked restriction of elevation in adduction and a positive forced duction test. A diagnosis of Brown syndrome was made. The pathology involves which of the following muscles?
questions.solution:
Brown syndrome occurs due to mechanical restriction caused by a congenitally tight superior oblique sheath or by the impaired movement of the superior oblique tendon through the trochlea. It may be acquired in some cases.

Contracture of the superior oblique leads to restriction of its antagonistic muscle, the inferior oblique and that is why the patient presents with absence of elevation in adduction.

questions.text: Brown’s syndrome simulates which muscle palsy?
questions.solution:
Brown’s superior oblique tendon sheath syndrome simulates palsy of inferior oblique muscle. In both of these cases, there is a limited elevation of the eye in adduction. 

Brown’s superior oblique tendon sheath syndrome is a cause of restrictive squint.The forced duction test is positive.

Differential diagnoses of Brown's syndrome:

  1. Inferior oblique palsy- differentiated by a positive head-tilt test (negative in Brown's syndrome) and a negative forced duction test (positive in Brown's syndrome)
  2. Primary superior oblique overaction- differentiated by negative forced duction test (Positive in Brown's syndrome)

questions.text: Identify the condition.
questions.solution:
The given image classically depicts an A pattern esotropia. Relative convergence on upgaze (esotropia increases on upgaze) is a feature of A-pattern esotropia.

A or V pattern heterotropia:

  • "V" or "A" patterns occur when the relative contributions of the superior rectus and inferior oblique to elevation, or of the inferior rectus and superior oblique to depression, are abnormal, resulting in the derangement of the balance of their horizontal vectors in up and downgaze.
  • Oblique muscle dysfunction is the commonest
  • "V" pattern is said to be significant when the difference between upgaze and downgaze is ≥15 Δ.
  • "A" pattern is considered significant if the difference between upgaze and downgaze is ≥10 Δ.

The image below shows A and V pattern heterotropia

questions.text: A patient presents with left-sided head tilt which on straightening leads to right hypotropia. This increases on dextroversion and right head tilt. Paralysis of which of the following muscles is involved?
questions.solution:
Right superior rectus palsy is the cause for the given clinical scenario.

The three-step test, also known as the Parks-Bielschowsky three-step test, is a diagnostic test used to identify which muscle is paralyzed in the case of an acquired hypertropia. This method uses the cover-uncover test, with or without the Maddox rod to measure the amount of deviation in different head positions.

The three-step test may also be used to diagnose the less common inferior oblique or vertical rectus muscle palsy. It is designed for the diagnosis of a single paretic vertical muscle and is unreliable when there are multiple paretic muscles or in restrictive strabismus. This test may also help in identifying if a superior rectus palsy is true or simulated in a patient with an inhibitional palsy of the contralateral antagonist.

Using the three-step test in the above clinical scenario:

Step 1. Which eye is hypotrophic?

The eye hypotrophic in the primary position is the right eye. The paretic muscles can be right eye elevator or left eye depressor.

  • Right superior rectus
  • Right inferior oblique
  • Left inferior rectus
  • Left superior oblique

Step 2.Does the hypotropia increase in the right gaze or left gaze?

The hypotropia increases in right gaze.

Therefore, the paretic muscle must be either (1) one of the muscles whose primary action is elevating the right eye on the right gaze, or (2) one of the muscles whose primary action is depressing the left eye in the right gaze. The left inferior oblique and the right superior rectus both have a primary action of elevation in right gaze. Therefore, one of these muscles could be the paretic muscle. Likewise, the left superior oblique and the right inferior rectus have a primary action of depression in the right gaze and could be paretic. But since the left inferior oblique and the right inferior rectus did not meet step 1, they can be eliminated from the possible paretic muscles. This leaves us:

  • Left superior oblique 
  • Right superior rectus

Step 3. Does the hypotropia increase in the right head tilt or left head tilt?

The hypotropia increases in the right head tilt. If the deviation increases on right head tilt and decreases on left head tilt, as it does in this example patient, then the right superior rectus is implicated as the paretic culprit.
